Evaluation_Questions: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Comments_Questions: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
Comments_List: I learned how to use anthropological concepts to analyze other cultures' interpretations and understandings of space.

I had never taken an anthropology class before, so this opened my eyes to a lot of topics in that field. Also, I feel that I came away from the class perhaps a bit more jaded about outer space, but certainly more thoughtful about it, particularly what it means on a cultural level.
Understanding the various ways in which humans perceive and interact with outer space
Learned about ethnography and other anthropological techniques; also learned about how anthropology relates to space.

This course was an awesome introduction to anthropology through the lens out outer space. Taking this course gave me insights about how anthropologists think, as well as challenging some of my beliefs about nature and culture and the existence of human nature. In the final project, I got to dive deep into an aspect of "Martian" culture, learning a lot about a specific topic but also applying the anthropological principles I had learned.
Ethnography, reading anthropology texts, understanding humans relationship to outer space

I learned a lot about the history of space as seen from different cultures (ancient Native American mythologies up through the Space Race of the 60s to present day and even thinking about the future, as well as how gender and race affect these thoughts). I also learned what their observations said about different people groups themselves and also a lot of the anthropological basics that these ways of thinking were grounded in.
I gained a familiarity with anthropological writing/reading, as well as how to analyze how we relate to space from an anthropological perspective.

In this class, we looked at a breadth of different topics like sci-fi, paintings, movies, linguistics, and museum curation. Every unit taught me how to look at these topics in a new and more informed/educated way. I now appreciate museums much more, pay more attention to how women are portrayed in sci fi, and more.
This course broadened my view of who space impacts and how it does so. I gained insight into the diverse narratives surrounding space exploration.
We learned about how different cultures view outer space and how that impacts different outer space concepts.

I really liked the format, although it was kind of an awkwardly large class size to do discussion/seminar-like questions in class-- it felt like fairly often we were only hearing the same opinions from the same people every time. I think I would have preferred either just a lecture, or a smaller class with more thoughtful debates/discussions. But I do get that the class was an awkward size for either of those options, and I'm super thankful that Professor Messeri did ont cap the class.

Lectures in this course were generally interesting, but the readings were often hardly discussed in class. Since many of the readings were also difficult to grasp due to their density, it would have been nice to have either in depth discussion of them or to have shorter/easier readings assigned.

Strengths: really engaging and interesting, well thought out and well taught, a good overview. I was going to list the diversity of the class as a weakness but actually I think it's a strength, especially in the world building and final project stages of the course.
Weaknesses: I guess the amount and density of reading could be kind of inconsistent? I'm sort of nitpicking because I don't have major weaknesses to complain about!
I liked the diversity of topics that we covered, but I wish there could have been a little more structure, and maybe something tying the whole semester together.

Strengths: Really interesting readings, class discussions, and the final project was so much fun! All the work we did felt meaningful and I learned a lot throughout the semester and in creating the final project. 
Weaknesses: It would have been helpful to have more guidance for some of the readings so that I could get the most out of them
Lectures are fantastic, reading is manageable, and assignments are fairly graded. I don't know if I would change anything.

The strengths of the course are how interesting the material is, how passionate Prof. Messeri is about that material, and the engaging final project. One of the weaknesses of the course was that it probably would have been more engaging as a smaller class (though that's nobody's fault.)

This class is very engaging, and Professor Messeri is great! This class covered a lot of topics that spoke to my heart, like exoplanets and Mars colonization. The readings were interesting, and I can't think of too many weaknesses for this class.

Professor Messeri makes this class amazing. The class is very structured, as it is broken down into 4 units, and it was taught in a hybrid manner so that people who like lectures and people who like seminars are both happy. All of the readings are very interesting and play some sort of role in our class discussion. Everyone feels like they can participate in class because of the way the professor responds to students' ideas.

Yes, this course was attended by many people who had never taken anthropology or were STEAM majors taking it for a Humanities credit and they had a great time taking it. The course is very accessible for people of all disciplines and should be taken by anyone with an interest in space and its significance in culture.
Yes definitely! Especially if the final project stays as great as it was this year :)
Great at combining an interest in space science with humanities and social science, with really interesting class readings.

Absolutely take this course! It will be some of the most exciting, least drudgery-like work you do at Yale, especially the world building and final project at the end of the course. Every lecture was well thought out and although the class is technically a lecture, it frequently felt more like a seminar. You have to be motivated to do the reading and participate, but if you do, it's really interesting and worthwhile.

I would recommend this course for those who are interested in space and humanity's interest in space. However, I would not recommend this course to those who are looking for a rigorous anthropological exploration of non-human domains of being. This course is taught more for students without an anthropology background.
YES
Yes! The class lies at a very interesting intersection of science and anthropology. The content was engaging and the class was low-stress. Professor Messeri is a wonderful teacher.

I absolutely would recommend this course. It's fascinating learning about space from a more human-based point of view. Our course was laid out so that we had 4 reading responses, a midterm paper, and a final project and paper. Other than that, all readings were extremely manageable and Professor Messeri is an incredible lecturer. If you're looking for a 5th credit or a fun class to add to your schedule, definitely take this.
Yes, if you're interested in the intersection of anthropology and space.

Take this course! It is so fun, especially if you're a lover of sci-fi and outer space. As a STEM major, it was just a cool outlet to talk about all the warm and fuzzy reasons I love space. Definitely one of the most fun classes I've taken at Yale! The final project was a blast as well.
Yes definitely! Very cool blend of concepts and I learned about interesting idea that I'll continue to ponder for years.
I would 100% recommend this course to other students regardless of major because I think there's an area of interest for everyone touched on.
Yes!! This class changed my perspective on many things, including outer space, art, culture, and humanity. Definitely take this class if Professor Messeri is teaching it!
